responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: Nah, I don't really go out looking for new mates like some blokes do. It's more like, they just sort of fall into my life, and I hope we stick together. Like Harry, I reckon we've been through so much together, and even when things get rough, there's always a chance to mend what's broken. And then there's little Pigwidgeon – Sirius sent him to me, and though he's a bit of a handful, he's become a part of the family. It's funny how even in the darkest times, a small thing can bring you some joy and remind you that you're not alone. Making friends, especially close ones, isn't something you do every day – it's about finding people who'll have your back no matter what.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: Well, I reckon when you've got a bunch of odd stuff going on like dealing with ghosts and all sorts of magical creatures, you don't have much choice but to dive into all sorts of random topics. It's not really something I plan out, but more like, one minute you're trying to figure out how to make a platter that looks like it's rotting to please some friendly ghosts, and the next you're pondering over the mysteries of Thestrals. And let's not forget all the daft ideas that pop up in my head at Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes. There's always something new and exciting to learn about, even if it means risking a bit of mischief along the way!

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: Seeing others cry can really knock me off balance, especially when it's someone I care about. Like when I watched Harry do the First Task, or when Hermione was hurting so much at the hands of Bellatrix—it's tough, mate. It's like you wanna be there for them, ya know? But sometimes it feels like you're just standing there, helpless, and it can make you want to cry too. Then again, I try not to let my emotions get the best of me when we've got bigger battles to fight.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response: Mate, I reckon you've got me pegged right – I'm not exactly the planner type, especially not for backup plans of backup plans. Usually, I just try to keep my head down and my wand ready, and let Harry and Hermione sort out the complicated stuff. But when it comes down to it, I'll do anything to look after my friends, even if it means jumping into something without a clue. And hey, sometimes those spur-of-the-moment decisions turn out alright, like saving Harry's baby from the future or sticking with Lockhart through his memory mess-up. It's about being there for each other, you know?

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: Well, I'd like to think I can stay pretty cool under the pressure, but let's be honest, I'm more the guy who gets a bit twitchy and jumpy. It's just how I am—I worry a lot, especially about my mates. But when it really comes down to it, like when Harry went off to face all sorts of dangers, I always manage to find that bit of bravery and stick with him. That's what being a friend is all about, isn't it? It's not about staying calm; it's about being there no matter what, even if your nerves are shot.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: Well, I reckon it depends on the event. If it’s somewhere where I already know folks, like maybe a Quidditch match or a get-together at the Burrow, then yeah, I’m more likely to stick with the familiar faces. But when it comes to meeting new people, especially if it’s a situation where you gotta stand up for something or someone, I don’t shy away from that. I’ve learned that sometimes, stepping out of your comfort zone can lead to some of the best moments and friends you could ever ask for. Like meeting Harry on that train ride to Hogwarts—I didn't exactly think it'd end up changing my life, but here we are. And even though there were times when things got pretty rocky between us, like when Harry thought I was spying on him, we always managed to pull through together. So, while I might not be the first one to introduce myself to strangers at a social event, when it really matters, I’ll do what needs to be done.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: Nah, I reckon I don't really have the luxury of finishing one thing before diving into another. With all the adventures and scrapes we've been in, Harry, Hermione, and me, there's never really been a chance to take a breather, you know? One project's just gotta blend right into the next. It's like playing Wizard's Chess, you've gotta think a few moves ahead but also react to whatever comes up right away. And hey, it keeps things exciting, if you ask me. Plus, I'd rather have a bunch of half-done projects than lose focus on what matters most, like friendship and helping those who need it.

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: Yeah, I reckon I am pretty sentimental. There’s something about losing someone like Dobby, or thinking back to my wedding day – even though it’s mostly a blur – that really hits me hard. And then there are those moments, like when I saw Harry and Hermione on Chocolate Frog cards, where I feel so proud but also just a bit emotional thinking about all we’ve been through. I guess I’m one to hold onto memories and let them shape me, whether they’re filled with laughter or tears.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: Organizing tools? Nah, I'm not really one for that. I mean, sure, schedules and lists sound neat and all, but they're kind of like trying to pin down a niffler – just when you think you've got everything under control, something else pops up and screws everything up. Besides, I've always found that things tend to work out better when I just wing it and rely on my mates. And when it comes to remembering stuff, well, I've got a pretty good memory for the important things, like which jinx works best on which prat, or where to find the best Chocolate Frogs in Diagon Alley. But hey, if it helps George keep track of all the crazy products we have at Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes, I suppose I could give it a try. Who knows, maybe I'll even find a way to make it a bit mischievous.

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: Well, blimey, sometimes even a small blooper can make me feel like I'm not up to snuff, y'know? Like when I ran off during the Yule Ball instead of asking Fleur out—I really kicked myself for that one. But you know what? It's my mates that pull me through. And Harry, he's got this knack for boosting my confidence, even if it means sneaking me some kind of potion to pretend it's luck. In the end, it's all about having someone believe in you, even when you don't believe in yourself. And hey, at least I've got the chess set sorted! That was one time where a stupid mistake didn't bring me down; I managed to save the day with a bit of risky play. So yeah, doubts creep in, but I reckon I've got enough grit to shake 'em off and do what needs to be done.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: Nah, I don't reckon I'd just walk up to someone and start chatting unless I know there's a good reason to. Like, when I first met Hermione on that train, I kinda did, but it wasn't exactly smooth sailing at first. And with Harry, well, we clicked straight away, but that took some serious turns to get us where we needed to be. So yeah, I'm more the type to let a friendship grow naturally, rather than force it. But once you're in, you're in for the long haul, no matter what.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: Well, I gotta say, I'm more the type to dive straight into the action rather than sit around talking about what things might mean. Don't get me wrong, it's all well and good to have a bit of fun with ideas and theories, but when it comes down to it, I prefer doing something practical and real. You know, like figuring out a new joke product at the shop or getting stuck into a Quidditch match. Talking about books and stuff just isn’t really my cuppa tea. I’d rather be out there, living and breathing the adventure, ya know?

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: Well, I reckon it depends on the situation, doesn't it? There've been times when I've let my heart rule, like choosing to stick with Harry and Hermione even when things got really tough. And then there's other times, like that night at Xenophilius Lovegood’s, where my head told me we needed to be careful, but my heart was all for going after the Hallows right away. I guess I'm more inclined to follow my heart, but I try not to ignore what my head's telling me either. After all, we've faced some pretty dark stuff, and both have come in handy.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: Well, I reckon there's a bit of both in me. Sometimes, I just want to dive headfirst into whatever feels right at the moment, especially if it means having an adventure or a good laugh with Harry and Hermione. But other times, like when we've got some big plan to take down You-Know-Who, I find myself wishing I could be more like Fred and George, who seem to have everything figured out with their pranks and all. In the end, it's really about being there for my friends and doing what needs to be done, even if it means stepping back from the impulsive side and thinking things through. After all, it's not always about the excitement—it's about being brave and loyal, especially in the tough times.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: Well, I reckon I do worry about making a good impression sometimes, especially when I'm trying to prove myself or when something big's happening, like during the Triwizard Tournament. But honestly, most of the time, I'm just doing my thing with Harry and Hermione. I mean, who cares what other folks think as long as you've got mates who've got your back? And let's face it, I can be a bit thick sometimes, so maybe it's better if I just stick to being me, even if that means getting a bit of ribbing now and then. But hey, it's the small moments and the laughs with my friends that really matter, right?

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: Yeah, I reckon I do enjoy group activities, especially when it comes to Quidditch or just hanging out with mates. There's something magical about being surrounded by people you care about, whether we're cheering on a game, planning pranks, or even at a party where everything feels a bit off but you've got your friends by your side. It's like, even when things get a bit hairy, knowing you're not alone makes all the difference. And honestly, it's great because you can have someone else to watch your back when things turn dangerous.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: Well, I reckon it depends on the book or movie. If it's something that really gets me thinking and I can't just sit there all mopey about not knowing exactly how it ends, then yeah, I do like it. It's kind of like figuring out a new way to defeat a dark wizard or working out a tricky plan to get something done – it gives you a bit of a challenge, you know? And it's nice to have those moments where you're not sure what's going to happen next; it keeps things interesting. But I also like a clear ending, you know, when everything wraps up nice and neat, especially after all the mess we've been through with You-Know-Who.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: Well, I reckon helping others out does make me pretty happy. Like when I got that Special Award for helping out during the Triwizard Tournament, it was great to get the points for Gryffindor, but seeing everyone cheer for me, knowing they appreciated what I did... that really touched me. And then there's stuff like becoming godfather to Harry and Ginny's little one, or just generally being there for Harry through all the madness—we're in this together, ya know? But, yeah, seeing others do well because of a bit of help from yours truly, that's something that warms the cockles of my heart. It's not always about me, but about us and how we can pull together. That's where I find a lot of my happiness, I suppose.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: Well, I've got to admit, there are times when I do feel like I've got too many interests. But when it comes down to it, I reckon I always end up focusing on what really matters, like helping out my mates or trying to make a difference with our joke shop. It's funny how sometimes, when you've got so much on your plate, you just gotta pick something that makes you feel alive—like the time we came up with that ghost-themed platter, which wasn't exactly haunted but sure was a hit. And honestly, seeing Harry take on challenges and Hermione dive into her studies gives me a lot of inspiration. I just hope I'm doing alright, you know, with all this stuff going on.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: Yeah, I do worry a lot that things will go south. It's just... when you've been through as much as we have, it's hard not to think about all the ways things can go wrong. But even when my gut's twisting in knots, there's always this flicker of hope too. Especially knowing how Harry and Hermione always seem to pull through, even when it looks like everything's about to hit the fan. And honestly, that loyalty and courage they've got—they've done more than just help me out; they've made me believe in myself too, even when I'm the one who's messed up. So, yeah, I worry, but I also hold onto hope, because I reckon if we stick together, we can get through pretty much anything.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: Well, I reckon you could say I've had my fair share of moments where I wished I wasn't the one leading the charge. It's not exactly my forte, and let's be honest, I usually end up bungling things more than helping. But when it really matters—when friends are counting on me—I do my best to step up. Like that time with the Wizard's Chess, I didn't have much choice, did I? Just had to think quick and do what was right for the team, even if it meant sacrificing myself. And yeah, sometimes I get a bit frosty or angry, like when Harry and Hermione didn't quite understand where I was coming from, but at the end of the day, I'll always try to do what's best for everyone, especially if it means keeping us all safe and together.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: Well, I reckon you could say that. I'm more the kind who'd rather grab a broomstick and zoom around than try to draw anything halfway decent. Art classes always felt a bit pointless to me, like trying to catch a Niffler with your bare hands. It's not really my cup of tea, but hey, I've got other skills that come in handy—like knowing how to get out of trouble with a good laugh or two, or figuring out how to use some of Fred and George's stuff in a pinch. Artistic talent isn't really where my strengths lie, but that's okay—I've got Harry and Hermione for brains and bravery, so I guess I just stick to being loyal and all right at magic.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: Well, I reckon people need both, don't they? Feelings can get us into trouble, sure, but they're what drive us to do daft and daring things like saving a hippogriff or standing up against Umbridge. And when it comes to mates, you can't just rely on being rational all the time. Sometimes you've gotta follow your gut, even if it means flying off the handle at someone like Percy. So, yeah, I think we need a bit of both to keep things balanced and make this world a bit more magical.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Well, I reckon I'm more the type to dive straight into whatever's needed done, rather than dilly-dally about it. It’s like how I always rushed to help Harry and Hermione, even if I wasn't sure I could handle it. I guess I figure getting chores out of the way first means you can actually enjoy your downtime without thinking about all the stuff you're avoiding. But hey, there's nothing wrong with a bit of relaxation too, especially if it means sharing a laugh with friends. That's worth more than any chore list, really.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: Nah, I don't reckon I do. Watching people argue isn't really my cup of tea, especially when it feels like everyone's losing their cool. It's more like, if there's an argument going on, I'm probably right in the middle of it, trying to sort things out or maybe even causing a bit of a stir myself. But seeing others go at it? More likely than not, I'll be feeling for whoever's getting the raw end of the deal and hoping to help patch things up later. After all, you never know how much it might affect the people around you, like Harry and me after I heard that talk we weren't meant to, or that time with Hermione and Lavender. Arguments can cut deep, even among friends.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: Nah, I don't usually try to stay out of the spotlight unless there's a really good reason to. Like, sometimes, it can get a bit much, you know? My bros and I have had our fair share of sticky situations where it'd be better to just blend into the background. But most of the time, I figure it's worth standing up for what's right, even if it means drawing some unwanted attention. And hey, with Harry around, I'm bound to get noticed anyway!

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: Yeah, my mood can flip faster than a flipping coin, especially when it comes to stuff that matters. Like, one minute I’m feeling low because of some trouble or another, and then something good happens, like seeing Hermione, and I’m right back up again. It’s all about the ups and downs, really, but the lows seem to hit me harder sometimes. I guess that’s part of being human though, isn’t it? Just gotta keep laughing and moving forward with the gang.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response: Well, sometimes I do get a bit grumpy when things don’t go as fast as I’d like, but I reckon it’s more about the stress getting to me rather than losing patience over efficiency. I mean, I’ve had my fair share of times where I felt like I wasn’t measuring up, and it’s not exactly easy being around someone who’s always pointing out how to do things better all the time. But at the end of the day, I’m all about sticking together with my mates, even when things get a bit tough. After all, without Harry and Hermione, I’d probably have gotten myself into a lot more trouble than I already have.

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: Well, I reckon I've done my fair share of waiting until the last minute. It’s kinda like leaving the Burrow, where you never really know what might happen until you're right on the doorstep of trouble or adventure. But when it counts, I try to step up. Like that time with the Wizard’s Chess, I had to think fast to let Harry and Hermione get to the Stone, even if it meant I'd be stuck as a game piece for a while. And yeah, there’ve been other times too, where it felt like our luck could run out any second, but somehow we manage. It’s all about sticking together and having each other’s backs, really.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response: Well, you know, watching all those ghosts at Hogwarts parties did make me curious, but it's more like I'm trying to figure out how we can still feel so close to someone even after they're gone. Like, when Fred died, it was like a part of me went missing, but talking about him with George or seeing things he’d love still feels like he’s there in a way. And then there’s Dobby—his funeral hit me hard, made me think about what we leave behind and how our actions matter even after we’re not around anymore. Seeing Thestrals for the first time really brought home the fact that facing death changes you, makes you see things others can't. It’s like, once you’ve seen something that terrible, you’re never quite the same again, but maybe that’s a good thing. It’s taught me a lot about being strong for my friends, especially Harry. But honestly, all this talk about what happens after... it’s pretty tricky stuff. I mean, Divination was a load of rubbish in my opinion, but the real stuff, the losses we’ve faced, they stick with you. They shape you and your thoughts about everything, including what might be waiting on the other side.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: Nah, I don't reckon I fancy being on my own much. I've always been one for having mates around. Growing up at The Burrow, there was never a shortage of loud, silly people to keep me company, even if we didn't have much else. And then meeting Harry and Hermione at Hogwarts, well, that just proved to me that you can find the most loyal friends in the craziest places. Sure, there've been times when things got a bit rocky between us, but in the end, there's nothing like having someone by your side when things get tough. And let's face it, they usually do when you're dealing with dark wizards and such!

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: Highly theoretical discussions? Eh, sometimes they can be a bit of a drag, y'know? I mean, it's not that I don't appreciate the magic behind it all, but there's a lot of stuff that feels more like guesswork than real magic. I'd rather be out there doing something practical, like a bit of Quidditch or even pulling off a decent prank with George. But hey, when it comes down to it, I'll stick around and try to make sense of it all because it matters to my friends, even if it doesn't always spark much interest in me.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: Well, it's not always easy, mate. I mean, take Hermione for instance—she came from a totally different background than me, and at first, it was hard to see past that. But you know, spending so much time together, going through thick and thin, really helps you understand someone, even if their world doesn't look like yours. It's all about being there for each other, and listening when they need to talk, even if their experiences are completely foreign. And sometimes, yeah, it can hurt, like when things get complicated or when someone doesn't see you the way you want them to, but in the end, true friends, they stick with you no matter what. That's what I've learned, anyway.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: Well, I've been known to dither around a bit, especially when things get tough or when I'm not sure what to do. But when it comes down to it, and I mean really down to it, like when we had to save Buckbeak or go through that bloody chess game to get to the Philosopher’s Stone, I try to make a decision quick. It might not always be the smartest choice, but it’s better than doing nothing at all. Postponing stuff can just lead to more trouble, and sometimes, it’s best to act before you think too much and chicken out, like I did with Fleur.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: Second-guessing? Nah, I don't really do that. When it comes down to it, I usually just go with what my gut tells me, especially when it's about helping my mates. There've been times though, like when Hermione had to go back and save us all, where I wish I knew the whole story before we jumped in. But hey, that's just how it goes, right? You make a choice, sometimes it's a bit messy, but as long as you stand by your friends, it's worth it. And let's be honest, without the odd mistake or two, life would be boring.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: Yeah, definitely. After a tough week, there's nothing like a good laugh and some time with mates to make things right again. I reckon it's not just about escaping the stress, but also about finding that bit of warmth and normalcy that helps you keep going. Just like stepping into the Three Broomsticks feels like home, even when everything else is spinning out of control. And hey, a bit of wizard chess or a few rounds of Butterbeer never hurt anyone either. Helps you forget the worries, even if it's just for a little while.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response:
Interviewer: Do you enjoy going to art museums?

Well, to be honest, I've never really been one for art museums. It's not like there's much magic involved, is there? More my speed would be somewhere like Zonko's, where you can find all sorts of fun and mischievous stuff. Art museums just seem a bit... quiet, y'know? Not much room for a bit of banter or a laugh. But then again, I've never really given it a proper try, so maybe there's some charm I'm missing out on. Maybe Hermione could explain the appeal, though she'd probably have to do it slowly for me to understand.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response: Sometimes I do, mate. It's like I'm always tripping over my own feet trying to figure out what someone else is thinking or feeling. I've had my fair share of messing things up, like when I got all jealous of Harry and Hermione or when I thought Harry was being all secretive. But at the end of the day, it's the close scrapes and standing up for each other that really show who your mates are. Even if we bicker or drift apart sometimes, it's those times when we stick together that make everything else worth it. So yeah, I might not always get it right away, but I learn from those mistakes and try harder next time to keep the friendship going strong.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: Nah, I don't really go for to-do lists much. I mean, I know they're supposed to keep you on track, but sometimes life just throws you curveballs when you least expect it, doesn't it? Like that time with the poisoned chocolate, or even the Daily Prophet draw winning, which we stumbled upon rather than planned. It's more about being there for your mates when things get hairy and having a bit of a laugh along the way. Besides, I reckon if you've got a good group of friends, like Harry and Hermione, they'll keep you straight without needing some fancy list.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: Well, I'd say I feel insecure more than I'd like to admit. There've been times when I've doubted myself, especially when compared to Harry or Hermione. But then, there's always this hope that pushes me through, knowing that my friends believe in me. It's kind of like playing a game where you're not sure if you're going to win, but you still give it your all. And in the end, it's not just about winning but about having each other's backs, no matter what. That's what keeps me going.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: Er, phone calls? I reckon you've got the wrong bloke here. In our world, we don't exactly make phone calls – more like send owls or use Floo powder, though I must say I'm not much for Floo powder. It's all a bit muggle, isn't it? And to be honest, I'd rather have a face-to-face chat with someone than try to explain things through one of those. Plus, there's always the chance of running into Peeves or something worse if you're not careful! But yeah, avoiding talking to people? That's not really my thing, even if sometimes I can be a bit of a git and say stuff I shouldn't. At the end of the day, I value my friends too much to shy away from a good old chinwag.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: Well, I guess you could say I do, but not really on purpose. It's more like, when stuff gets thrown at us, we have no choice but to figure out how to deal with it. Like when Hermione suddenly goes all out with classes, or when I realize that Thestrals are connected to seeing death. Those aren't things I'd normally think about, but there you go—sitting right in front of you, demanding you pay attention. And sometimes, it's about understanding people's pain, like Neville's or even thinking about Fred. So yeah, maybe I do spend time understanding different views, especially when they're tied up in the real mess of things we've been through. But let's be honest, I'm not the best at it; I usually need my friends to nudge me along or explain it to me.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: Well, I suppose it depends on what you call "initiating activities." Sometimes I'm just there, ready to back my mates up when they need me most. Other times, like when we're planning something to cheer someone up or keep spirits high, I might be the one suggesting a game of wizard chess or a trip to the Three Broomsticks. But really, if there's anything to do with keeping our friendship strong and facing whatever challenges come our way, I'll definitely step up. It's not always about starting things; sometimes it's about being there for each other no matter what.

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: Yeah, getting back on track is pretty important to me, especially when things go haywire. I mean, remember that time with the flying car? Nearly got myself killed and missed the start of term, but once we were grounded and safe, my main thing was trying to lighten the mood with jokes and just being there for Harry and Hermione. And even when I was stuck in the Hospital Wing with my leg all messed up or avoiding Lavender because my head hurt too much to deal with her, what I really wanted was to be with my friends and do what needed to be done. So yeah, I reckon getting back on track and being there for the people who matter most is kinda my top priority, even if I don't always show it the best way.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: Yeah, I mean, mistakes stick with you, don't they? Like that time I messed up with Harry and thought he was keeping secrets from me... or when I let Fleur get away at the Yule Ball. But you know, it's kind of like what Hermione always says—learn from them and move on. And I have moved on. Those moments taught me a lot about trust and bravery, stuff I needed to learn to be there for my mates and face Voldemort. It's not like I forget 'em, but I try not to let them hold me back. Plus, when you've got friends who've got your back, like Harry did with that bezoar, well, it makes it easier to forgive yourself.

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: Well, I reckon there’s a lot more important things to think about than why we’re all here in the first place, like how we can stick together and get through the tough times. Sure, I’ve had my fair share of losses and shadows hanging over me, especially thinking about Fred and facing things like Thestrals and knowing what they mean. But diving deep into big questions like the meaning of life? Nah, that’s more Hermione’s style. I’m more focused on keeping my mates safe and ready for whatever comes our way next. Even if it means dealing with Professor Trelawney’s hazy predictions or the hard truth about what war does to people. At the end of the day, I think the meaning of life is kind of wrapped up in those you care about, isn’t it? That’s where I find my real magic.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response: Well, I reckon there've been times when my emotions have gotten the better of me, like when I thought Harry didn't trust me anymore. That hurt pretty bad, and it took me a while to sort that out. But at the end of the day, it's my mates that keep me grounded. Even if I do feel jealous or angry sometimes, like when Malfoy goes off on Hermione, I try to use that to be a bit stronger and look out for them. It's not always easy, and I've messed up plenty of times, but I guess in the thick of things, I do my best to stay in control and not let my feelings make me do something rash. After all, we've got enough dangers flying at us without adding my mood swings to the mix!

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: Nah, I don't go out of my way to protect people from looking bad when they've really messed up. Like when Scabbers—er, Wormtail—was exposed as a traitor, I couldn't pretend it wasn't true, even though it hit hard. But there's a difference between calling out someone's mistakes and being a right git about it. I've had my moments where I've said stuff I shouldn't have, like the time I mocked Hermione after she and Cormac... you know. That didn't sit well with me later, but I reckon it's better to just be honest and try to make things right afterward, rather than sweeping things under the rug. Of course, we've all had those times when we've hurt each other, like with Harry during the Triwizard Tournament, but in the end, it's about picking up the pieces and sticking together, no matter what.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: Well, I reckon it's a bit of both really. When it comes to facing the dark stuff, like the Calamity or You-Know-Who, I tend to just dive right in without thinkin' too much about it. That's where the spontaneous bursts come in, I guess. But when it’s about the day-to-day, like exams or even just a game of chess, I try to keep things organized and plan out my moves. Of course, I can get a bit scattered sometimes, especially when it's all goin' down around me, but I've learned that a quick side-step or roll can be just as valuable as a well-thought-out plan. And let's not forget, it's the friends who help you keep focused, no matter how chaotic things get.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: Yeah, it's something that crosses my mind, especially when things get all complicated around here. You know, with everything that happens, I can't help but worry that my mates might start thinking I'm not pulling my weight or that I'm always messing up. But at the same time, I've seen firsthand how important it is to stick together through thick and thin. So even if there are times when I feel like I've let them down, I hope they know I'm always trying my best to be there for them. And honestly, I reckon they'd give me another chance if I ever messed up big time. After all, we've been through so much together, it's hard to just give up on each other.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: Working alone? Nah, I reckon that wouldn't suit me too well. I've always been better with folks around, cracking jokes, or just being there for a laugh or to lend a hand. Like when I was with Harry and Hermione, we might've had our ups and downs, but facing stuff alone? That's not my cup of tea. I'm more about the team effort, ya know? It's all about having mates by your side, especially when things get tough. Plus, where's the fun in it if you can't share the sweets afterwards?

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: Well, I reckon it depends on who you're asking. In the middle of battling dark wizards and all sorts of nasty creatures, thinking about stuff like whether there's more to life than just surviving seems kinda far-fetched. But then again, when you've got some downtime and you're missing your mate Fred or thinking about the losses you've faced, maybe it's good to mull over those big questions. It doesn't change the fact that we've got to deal with the real dangers around us, though. So, yeah, sometimes it feels like a waste of time, but other times it helps you find your footing again.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: Well, I reckon there's something special 'bout places where everyone's buzzing around, ain't there? There's this sort of energy, you know? It feels like anything can happen, and it's usually right when you're trying to get some peace that chaos breaks loose. But honestly, what I really love is being surrounded by friends, whether we're all laughing our heads off in a crowded place or just sitting quietly in a corner somewhere. Both have their charm, but it's the people that make the difference.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: Well, I wouldn't say I can read someone's feelings just by looking at them, but over the years, spending so much time with Harry and Hermione, you pick up on the little things. Like when Harry goes all quiet and distant, there's usually something big weighing on his mind. And Hermione, she can be sharp as a razor, but you can see right through those tough words to the worry or sadness beneath. It's all about being there for each other, really. Sometimes you have to dig a bit deeper to understand what's going on with your mates, especially when things get rough. But that's what true friendship is all about, isn't it? Being there even when it's hard to tell what's wrong.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: Yeah, I do get overwhelmed sometimes, especially when there's so much going on around me. It's hard not to feel the pressure, what with the Triwizard Tournament and all that other stuff. But I try to hold onto the good things, like my friends and family, to keep me going. It helps to know that even though things can get really dark, we're in it together. That's why I always say, just keep pushing through, you know? And don't forget to keep a bit of humor around, it makes the tough times a little easier to bear.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: Well, I've gotta say, it depends on what we're talkin' about. When it comes to exams or somethin', sometimes I can slip up a bit, especially if there's a bit of chaos goin' on around me. But when it's about me and my mates, like Harry and Hermione, I reckon I don’t skip a beat. I might not always be the quickest on the uptake or the most steady-handed on the Quidditch pitch, but when it comes down to it, I'll do whatever it takes to keep us all safe and get the job done. Even if that means takin' a leap of faith and doin' things a bit more... well, let's call it 'spontaneous'. After all, it's not just about finishin' tasks, it's about stickin' with your friends through thick and thin, right?

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: Well, I reckon there's always been a bit of curiosity there when it comes to controversial stuff. But at the end of the day, I'm more worried about my mates and keeping us all safe than I am about controversial topics. Sometimes, though, you gotta dig into those tricky bits to figure out what's going on, like with that locket or Scabbers being Wormtail. It ain't easy, and it can tear you up inside, but if it helps Harry and Hermione, I'll do it. Just wish we could do it without the betrayal and all that pain, y'know? But I guess that's part of being in the middle of all this dark wizard business.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: Well, I reckon I'd think twice before passing up a good opportunity, especially if it means someone else getting a leg up. But I've learned the hard way that sometimes it's worth stepping back for a mate. Like when I left being an Auror to help George out with the joke shop—that was tough, but seeing how much it meant to him, well, it felt right. And yeah, there's been times when I've felt a bit overshadowed or jealous, but in the end, if I know someone needs it more or will make better use of it, I'd probably hand it over. That's what mates do, isn't it? They watch each other's backs.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: Yeah, I reckon I do have a bit of a struggle with deadlines, especially when there's danger lurking around every corner. With all the adventures and the battles we've been through, it's hard to keep track of homework sometimes. But when it really matters, like saving Buckbeak or just plain sticking up for friends, I manage to get things done, even if it means flying through the air and stunning Death Eaters. It's all about what you prioritize, right? And for me, it's always been about my mates and doing the right thing, no matter what.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: Well, I reckon things have a way of working out when you've got good mates like Harry and Hermione by your side. Even when things look pretty grim, there's always a bit of hope that you can grab onto. And honestly, with the lot of us together, we've seen some pretty mad stuff, and we've managed to turn things around more than once. So yeah, I do feel confident that no matter what comes our way, we'll figure it out somehow. It's not just about being brave, though; it's about sticking together and believing in each other, even when we're not so sure about ourselves.
